data.title: What battles took place during the Filipino
data.meta_description:
The Philippine American War began in Manila and lasted through
the fourth and fifth of February of 1899 with as many as 2,000
Filipino's killed wounded or captured. The other battles
included:
Santa Cruz,
Pagsanjan,
Paete,
Quingua,
Zapote River,
San Jacinto,
Tirad Pass,
Paye,
Catubig,
Makahambus Hill,
Cagayan de Misamis,
Agusan Hill,
Pulang Lupa,
Balangiga,
Mabitac,
Lonoy,
Siranaya,
Malalag River and the
Moro Uprising.
There were between 34,000 and 1,000,000 civilian non-combatants
killed and estimates of between 12,000 and 20,000 Filipino Rebel
Combatants killed. US losses reached 4,165 killed, but that
includes about 3,000 whose cause of death was by disease and
another 3,000 who were wounded in action. The Philippene
Constabulary and Philippine Scouts had an additional 2,000 killed
or wounded. The War ended on 4 July 1902 although among the Moro
and a few others continued hostilities until 15 June 1913.
data.text:
The Philippine American War began in Manila and lasted through the fourth and fifth of February of 1899 with as many as 2,000 Filipino's killed wounded or captured. The other battles included:

Santa Cruz,

Pagsanjan,

Paete,

Quingua,

Zapote River,

San Jacinto,

Tirad Pass,

Paye,

Catubig,

Makahambus Hill,

Cagayan de Misamis,

Agusan Hill,

Pulang Lupa,

Balangiga,

Mabitac,

Lonoy,

Siranaya,

Malalag River and the

Moro Uprising.

There were between 34,000 and 1,000,000 civilian non-combatants killed and estimates of between 12,000 and 20,000 Filipino Rebel Combatants killed. US losses reached 4,165 killed, but that includes about 3,000 whose cause of death was by disease and another 3,000 who were wounded in action. The Philippene Constabulary and Philippine Scouts had an additional 2,000 killed or wounded. The War ended on 4 July 1902 although among the Moro and a few others continued hostilities until 15 June 1913.

Where did most of the US Civil War battles take place?

Except for the battles in Gettysburg (Pennsylvania) and in Maryland, most of the battles took place in the South. While initially this included attacks in Virginia, later Union expeditions ranged from Texas and Missouri in the West to the cities of the mid-South, including Sherman's "March to the Sea" after burning Atlanta.
